Carpenter published ''Theoretical Astronomy Examined and Exposed – Proving the Earth not a Globe'' in eight parts from 1864 under the name ''Common Sense''.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oB1cxm_M-zUC|title= Theoretical astronomy examined and exposed, by 'Common sense'| publisher=| year= 1864}} He later emigrated to Baltimore, where he published ''One Hundred Proofs the Earth is Not a Globe'' in 1885.{{cite book | first= William | last= Carpenter | title= One Hundred Proofs that the Earth is Not a Globe | place= Baltimore| publisher= William Carpenter| year= 1885 | url= https://www.gutenberg.org/files/55387/55387-h/55387-h.htm | via= [[Project Gutenberg]]}} He wrote, "There are rivers that flow for hundreds of miles towards the level of the sea without falling more than a few feet – notably, the Nile, which, in a thousand miles, falls but a foot. A level expanse of this extent is quite incompatible with the idea of the Earth's convexity. It is, therefore, a reasonable proof that Earth is not a globe", as well as "If the Earth were a globe, a small model globe would be the very best – because the truest – thing for the navigator to take to sea with him. But such a thing as that is not known: with such a toy as a guide, the mariner would wreck his ship, of a certainty!, This is a proof that Earth is not a globe." * [[John Jasper]], an American slave turned prolific [[preacher]], echoed his friend Carpenter's sentiments in his most famous sermon "Der Sun do move", preached over 250 times, always by invitation. He claimed, "Low me ter ax ef de earth is roun', whar do it keep its corners? Er flat, squar thing has corners, but tell me where is de cornur uv er appul, ur a marbul, ur a cannun ball, ur a silver dollar."{{cite book | url= https://archive.org/stream/johnjasperunmatc00hatciala/johnjasperunmatc00hatciala_djvu.txt |title= John Jasper| first= William E. | last = Hatcher| publisher= Fleming Revell|date= 1908}}Garwood, p165 * In [[Brockport, New York|Brockport]], [[New York (U.S. state)|New York]], in 1887, M.C. Flanders argued the case of a flat Earth for three nights against two scientific gentlemen defending sphericity. Five townsmen chosen as judges voted unanimously for a flat Earth at the end. The case was reported in the ''Brockport Democrat''.''The Earth: Scripturally, Rationally, and Practically Described. A Geographical, Philosophical, and Educational Review, Nautical Guide, and General Student's Manual'', n. 17 (November 1, 1887), p. 7. cited in {{Cite news| first=Robert J. | last = Schadewald| title= Scientific Creationism, Geocentricity, and the Flat Earth| year= 1981|work= Skeptical Inquirer| url= http://www.lhup.edu/~dsimanek/crea-fe.htm| publisher= Lock Haven University| accessdate= August 21, 2010 |via= lhup.edu}} * Professor [[Joseph W. Holden]] of [[Maine]], a former [[justice of the peace]], gave numerous lectures in [[New England]] and lectured on flat Earth theory at the [[Columbian Exposition]] in Chicago. His fame stretched to [[North Carolina]] where the [[Statesville, North Carolina|Statesville]] ''Semi-weekly Landmark'' recorded at his death in 1900: "We hold to the doctrine that the Earth is flat ourselves and we regret exceedingly to learn that one of our members is dead."{{Cite book| title=Flat Earth|first= Christine | last= Garwood| publisher= Macmillan| year= 2007| isbn= 0-312-38208-1}} * After Rowbotham's death, [[Lady Elizabeth Blount]] (Elizabeth de Sodington Blount, née Elizabeth Anne Mould Williams) created the [[Universal Zetetic Society]] in 1893 in England and created a journal called ''Earth not a Globe Review'', which sold for twopence, as well as one called ''Earth'', which only lasted from 1901 to 1904. She held that the Bible was the unquestionable authority on the natural world and argued that one could not be a Christian and believe the Earth is a globe. Well-known members included [[E. W. Bullinger]] of the [[Trinitarian Bible Society]], Edward Haughton, senior moderator in natural science in [[Trinity College, Dublin]] and an archbishop. She repeated Rowbotham's experiments, generating some interesting counter-experiments, but interest declined after the First World War. The movement gave rise to several books that argued for a flat, stationary Earth, including ''Terra Firma'' by David Wardlaw Scott.{{cite book| first= David | last = Wardlaw Scott| title=Terra Firma| year=1901|url= https://archive.org/details/cu31924031764594| accessdate= December 13, 2010}} * In 1898, during his solo [[circumnavigation]] of the world, [[Joshua Slocum]] encountered a group of flat-Earthers in [[Durban, South Africa|Durban]], [[South Africa]]. Three [[Boers]], one of them a clergyman, presented Slocum with a pamphlet in which they set out to prove that the world was flat. [[Paul Kruger]], President of the [[South African Republic|Transvaal Republic]], advanced the same view: "You don't mean ''round'' the world, it is impossible! You mean ''in'' the world. Impossible!"{{cite book | first= Joshua | last = Slocum | title= Sailing Alone Around the World | place= New York | publisher= The Century Company | year= 1900 |chapter = 17–18 | url= http://www.ibiblio.org/eldritch/js/saaw.htm}} * [[Wilbur Glenn Voliva]], who in 1906 took over the [[Christian Catholic Apostolic Church|Christian Catholic Church]], a [[Pentecostal]] sect that established a utopian community in [[Zion, Illinois|Zion]], [[Illinois]], preached flat Earth doctrine from 1915 onwards and used a photograph of a twelve-mile stretch of the shoreline at [[Lake Winnebago]], [[Wisconsin]] taken three feet above the waterline to prove his point. When the [[airship Italia|airship ''Italia'']] disappeared on an expedition to the [[North Pole]] in 1928 he warned the world's press that it had sailed over the edge of the world. He offered a $5,000 award for proving the Earth is not flat, under his own conditions.{{cite web|url=http://blog.modernmechanix.com/2006/05/19/5000-for-proving-the-earth-is-a-globe/ |title=$5,000 for Proving the Earth is a Globe | Modern Mechanix |work= blog.modernmechanix.com |date= May 19, 2006 |accessdate=February 9, 2013}} Teaching a globular Earth was banned in the Zion schools and the message was transmitted on his [[WCBD]] radio station. * In 2018, astronomer [[Yaël Nazé]] analyzed the controversy over a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] thesis proposed by a student at the [[University of Sfax]], which defended a flat Earth as well as a [[geocentric model]] of the solar system and a [[Creation science|young Earth]]. The dissertation, which had not been approved by the committee overseeing environmental studies theses, had been made public and denounced in 2017 by professor Hafedh Ateb, a founder of the Tunisian Astronomical Society on his [[Facebook]] page.{{cite journal|last1=Nazé|first1=Yaël|authorlink=Yaël Nazé|title=A Doctoral Dissertation on a Geocentric Flat Earth: 'Zetetic' Astronomy at the University Level|journal=Skeptical Inquirer|date=2018|volume=42|issue=3|pages=12–14}} ===Flat Earth Society=== [[File:Flat earth.png|thumb|[[Azimuthal equidistant projection|Azimuthal equidistant projections of the sphere]] like this one have also been co-opted as images of the flat Earth model depicting Antarctica as an ice wallSchadewald, Robert J "The Flat-out Truth:Earth Orbits? Moon Landings? A Fraud! Says This Prophet" ''Science Digest'' July 1980Schick, Theodore; Lewis Vaughn ''How to think about weird things: critical thinking for a new age'' Houghton Mifflin (Mayfield) (October 31, 1995) {{ISBN|978-1-55934-254-4}} p. 197 surrounding a disk-shaped Earth.]] In 1956, [[Samuel Shenton]] set up the ''International Flat Earth Research Society'' (IFERS), better known as the [[Flat Earth Society]] from Dover, UK, as a direct descendant of the Universal Zetetic Society. This was just before the [[Soviet Union]] launched the first [[artificial satellite]], [[Sputnik]]; he responded, "Would sailing round the [[Isle of Wight]] prove that it were spherical? It is just the same for those satellites." His primary aim was to reach children before they were convinced about a spherical Earth. Despite plenty of publicity, the space race eroded Shenton's support in Britain until 1967 when he started to become famous due to the [[Apollo program]]. In 1972 Shenton's role was taken over by [[Charles K. Johnson]], a correspondent from California, US. He incorporated the IFERS and steadily built up the membership to about 3,000. He spent years examining the studies of flat and round Earth theories and proposed evidence of a [[conspiracy theory|conspiracy]] against flat Earth: "The idea of a spinning globe is only a conspiracy of error that Moses, Columbus, and FDR all fought..." His article was published in the magazine ''[[Science Digest]]'', 1980. It goes on to state, "If it is a sphere, the surface of a large body of water must be curved. The Johnsons have checked the surfaces of [[Lake Tahoe]] and the [[Salton Sea]] without detecting any curvature."{{cite web |author=Robert J. Schadewald |url=https://www.lockhaven.edu/~dsimanek/fe-scidi.htm |title=The Flat-out Truth |publisher=Lhup.edu |date= |accessdate=January 22, 2018}} The Society declined in the 1990s following a fire at its headquarters in California and the death of Johnson in 2001.{{cite web|author=Donald E. Simanek |url=http://www.lhup.edu/~dsimanek/flat/flateart.htm |title=The Flat Earth |publisher=Lhup.edu |date= |accessdate=February 9, 2013}} It was revived as a website in 2004 by Daniel Shenton (no relation to Samuel Shenton). He believes that no one has provided proof that the world is not flat.{{cite web|url=http://www.livescience.com/14754-ingenious-flat-earth-theory-revealed-map.html |title=Ingenious 'Flat Earth' Theory Revealed In Old Map |publisher=LiveScience |date= |accessdate=February 9, 2013}} ==Resurgence in the era of celebrity and social media== In the modern era, the proliferation of communications technology and social media platforms such as [[YouTube]], [[Facebook]]{{cite web|last1=Abbott|first1=Erica|title=Mark Zuckerberg Banning All Flat Earth Groups from Facebook Is A Hoax|url=http://www.business2community.com/facebook/mark-zuckerberg-banning-flat-earth-groups-facebook-hoax-01890594#WRFxzo1QOD9xCO2F.97|website=Business2community.com|publisher=Business2community|accessdate=19 August 2017}} and [[Twitter]] have given individuals, famous{{cite web|last1=Heigl|first1=Alex|url=http://people.com/celebrity/flat-earth-celebrities-world-not-round/|title=The Short List of Famous People Who Think the Earth Is Flat (Yes, Really)|website=People|date=February 20, 2017}} or otherwise, a platform to spread pseudo-scientific ideas and build stronger followings. The flat-Earth conjecture has flourished in this environment.{{cite news|url=http://www.denverpost.com/2017/07/07/colorado-earth-flat-gravity-hoax/|title=These Coloradans say Earth is flat. And gravity’s a hoax. Now, they’re being persecuted.|last1=Ambrose|first1=Graham|date=7 July 2017|work=[[The Denver Post]]|accessdate=19 August 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/jan/20/flat-earth-believers-youtube-videos-conspiracy-theorists|title=Flat-Earthers are back: 'It’s almost like the beginning of a new religion'|last1=Dure|first1=Beau|date=20 January 2016|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=19 August 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{cite web|last1=Herreria|first1=Carla|title=Neil deGrasse Tyson Cites Celebrity Flat-Earthers To Make A Point About Politics|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/neil-degrasse-tyson-flat-earth-pop-stars-flawed_us_58faa373e4b06b9cb91719ad|website=Huffingtonpost.com|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=19 August 2017}} The [[solar eclipse of August 21, 2017]], gave rise to numerous YouTube videos purporting to show how the details of the eclipse prove the Earth is flat.{{cite web|last1=Martin|first1=Sean|title=‘The sun hologram needs updating’ THIS is how flat Earthers explain the solar eclipse|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/science/841400/solar-eclipse-flat-earth-conspiracy-theory-reddit|website=Express.co.uk|publisher=The Express|accessdate=19 August 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Hickey|first1=Brian|title=What do flat Earthers think about Monday's solar eclipse?|url=http://www.phillyvoice.com/ask-hickey-what-are-flat-earthers-saying-about-mondays-eclipse/|website=Phillyvoice.com|publisher=Philly Voice|accessdate=19 August 2017}} Also in 2017, a scandal developed in Arab scientific and educational circles when a Tunisian PhD student submitted a thesis declaring Earth to be flat, unmoving, the center of the universe, and only 13,500 years old.{{cite web|last1=Guessoum|first1=Nidhal|title=PhD thesis: The earth is flat|url=http://gulfnews.com/opinion/thinkers/phd-thesis-the-earth-is-flat-1.2009202|website=Gulfnews.com|publisher=Gulf News|accessdate=19 August 2017}} ==Cultural references== The term ''flat-Earther'' is often used in a derogatory sense to mean anyone who holds ridiculously antiquated views. The first use of the term ''flat-Earther'' recorded by the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' is in 1934 in ''[[Punch (magazine)|Punch]]'': "Without being a bigoted flat-earther, [Mercator] perceived the nuisance ... of fiddling about with globes ... in order to discover the South Seas." {{cite web|title=Flat-Earth|publisher=Oxford English Dictionary|url=http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/71171?redirectedFrom=flat-earther#eid118363999|accessdate=July 29, 2013}} The term ''flat-earth-man'' was recorded in 1908: "Fewer votes than one would have thought possible for any human candidate, were he even a flat-earth-man." {{cite book|first=George B. |last=Shaw|title=Fabian Essays on Socialism (new ed.)|page=xviii|date=1908|url=https://archive.org/stream/fabianessaysins00olivgoog#page/n25/mode/2up}} ==See also== * [[List of topics characterized as pseudoscience]] * [[Biblical cosmology]] * [[Denialism]] * [[Earth's rotation]] * [[Geographical distance]] * [[Hollow Earth]] * [[Scientific mythology]] * [[Skepticism]] * [[World Turtle]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * [[Raymond Fraser|Fraser, Raymond]] (2007). ''When The Earth Was Flat: Remembering Leonard Cohen, Alden Nowlan, the Flat Earth Society, the King James monarchy hoax, the Montreal Story Tellers and other curious matters.'' Black Moss Press, {{ISBN|978-0-88753-439-3}} * Garwood, Christine (2007) ''Flat Earth: The History of an Infamous Idea'', Pan Books, {{ISBN|1-4050-4702-X}} * {{cite book |first= Rudolf| last=Simek |title=Heaven and Earth in the Middle Ages: The Physical World Before Columbus |publisher=The Boydell Press |date=1996 |others=Angela Hall (trans.) |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gXBSKZAlAdMC&pg=PR7 |accessdate=February 9, 2013 | isbn=9780851156088 }} * {{cite book | last = Plofker | first = Kim | title = Mathematics in India | date = 2009 | publisher = Princeton University Press | url = https://books.google.com/?id=DHvThPNp9yMC&pg=PA52&dq=The+earliest+such+cosmological+system+known+in+Indian+texts+is+a+non+spherical+model+of+the+earth#v=onepage&q=The%20earliest%20such%20cosmological%20system%20known%20in%20Indian%20texts%20is%20a%20non%20spherical%20model%20of%20the%20earth&f=false | ref = harv | isbn = 0691120676 }} ==External links== {{Commons category|Flat-earth theories}} * {{cite web|url=http://podcast.sjrdesign.net/shownotes_033.php|last=Robbins|first=Stuart|title=Episode 33: Flat Earth|publisher=Exposing PseudoAstronomy Podcast|date=2012-05-01}} * {{cite web|url=http://podcast.sjrdesign.net/shownotes_145.php|last=Robbins|first=Stuart|title=Episode 145: Modern Flat Earth Theory, Part 1|publisher=Exposing PseudoAstronomy Podcast|date=2016-09-05}} * {{cite web|url=http://podcast.sjrdesign.net/shownotes_149.php|last=Robbins|first=Stuart|title=Episode 149: Modern Flat Earth Thought, Part 2|publisher=Exposing PseudoAstronomy Podcast|date=2016-10-04}} * {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D2RDpPrKwl8|last1=Power|first1=Myles|last2=James|first2=James|title=Episode 146: The Lies of the Sun|publisher=League of Nerds (YouTube)|date=2016-10-31}} – Review of a pro-Flat Earth documentary. * [http://www.veritas-ucsb.org/library/russell/FlatEarth.html The Myth of the Flat Earth] * [https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg20227084.500-flat-universe-may-be-the-new-flat-earth.html The Myth of the Flat Universe] * [http://www.straightdope.com/classics/a2_087.html You say the earth is round? Prove it] (from [[The Straight Dope]]) * [http://archives.math.utk.edu//hypermail/historia/feb00/0164.html Flat Earth Fallacy] * [http://www.sacred-texts.com/earth/za/index.htm Zetetic Astronomy, or Earth Not a Globe by Parallax (Samuel Birley Rowbotham (1816–1884))] at sacred-texts.com * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ThPgMu2-ToM&feature=youtu.be&list=PLzL1qDngeVYU-9pNm1iRL8pTshEoAv363/ Flat Earth idea of the suns trajectory] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dtHuTVXZGFw&feature=youtu.be/ Flat Earth Theory of the Moon & Sun's paths around the world] {{pseudoscience}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Flat Earth theory| ]] [[Category:Early scientific cosmologies]] [[Category:Obsolete scientific theories]] [[Category:Pseudoscience]]

revision.comment: Repairing links to disambiguation pages - [[Wikipedia:Disambiguation pages with links|You can help!]]
removed [[Category:Statoil oil and gas fields]]; added [[Category:Equinor oil and gas fields]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox Oil field | name = Grane | country = [[Norway]] | location_map = North Sea | location_map_width = | location_map_text = | coordinates = {{coord|59.22|N|2.49|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_ref = | locblock = | offonshore = Offshore | operator = [[Statoil]] | partners = Statoil (38%)
[[Petoro]] (30%)
[[ExxonMobil]] (25.60%)
[[ConocoPhillips]] (6.40%) | image = | caption = | discovery = 1991 | startofproduction = 2003 | peakofproduction = 10 March 2006 | expectedabandonment = 2028 | oil_production_m3/d = 34000 | producingformations = Heimdal, Lista }} '''Grane''' ({{lang-no|Granefeltet}}) is an offshore [[oil field]] in the [[North Sea]] located {{convert|185|km|mi|abbr=on}} west of the city of [[Haugesund]] on the western coast of [[Norway]].{{cite web|url=http://www.subsea.org/projects/allbyregion.asp |title=List of Subsea Oil Gas Projects Offshore Europe(North) |publisher=Subsea.org |date= |accessdate=24 April 2011}} It is Norway's first heavy crude oil production field and [[Statoil]]'s largest heavy oil field in the [[Norwegian continental shelf]]. The oil from the field, located in Block 25/11 is transported to [[Sture terminal]] via [[Grane oil pipeline]].{{cite web|url=http://www.subsea.org/projects/listdetails.asp?ProjectID=169 |title=Subsea Oil & Gas Directory |publisher=Subsea.org |date= |accessdate=24 April 2011}} The injection gas is imported to Grane oil field from the [[Heimdal gas field|Heimdal]], located just north the field.{{cite web|url=http://www.statoil.com/AnnualReport2008/en/CountrySpotlight/Norway/Pages/3-1-7-1_OperationsNorthSea.aspx |title=Statoil.Operations North Sea |publisher=Statoil.com |date= |accessdate=24 April 2011}} {{cite journal | url= http://www.epmag.com/archives/features/186.htm | title= Grane gives up heavy Norway oil | author=Lyle, Don |date=January 2007 | journal=E&P magazine | accessdate= 2009-12-07 }} ==Ownership== The Grane field is operated by [[Statoil]]. Statoil holds 38%, [[Petoro]] – 30%, [[ExxonMobil]] – 25.60%, [[ConocoPhillips]] – 6.40%.{{cite web|url=http://www.conocophillips.com/EN/about/worldwide_ops/country/europe/Pages/norway.aspx |title=ConocoPhillips data |publisher=Conocophillips.com |date= |accessdate=24 April 2011}} ==Technical features== The field lies in {{convert|128|m}} of water at total depth of {{convert|1700|m}}. The reservoir is nearly {{convert|27|km2}} and has an average pay thickness of {{convert|50|m}} with an average porosity of 33% and permeability of 5–10 [[Darcy (unit)|Darcies]]. The reservoir consists of sandstones of Heimdal formation of Paleocene age, Lista formation and has high viscosity.{{cite web|url=http://www.npd.no/engelsk/cwi/pbl/en/index.htm |title=OLJEDIREKTORATET Norwegian Petroleum Directorate. Grane |publisher=Npd.no |date= |accessdate=24 April 2011}} ==Development history== Norsk Hydro and partners started development of the field in 1991. The Grane field started producing in September 2003. 31 production wells were put into operation. {{cite news | url= http://www.hydro.com/en/Press-room/News/Archive/2006/May/16979/ | title= Grane oil field success at OTC | publisher=Hydro News | author= | date=3 May 2006 | volume= | issue= | accessdate=2009-12-07 }} The facility was designed by [[Aker Solutions]] Engineering in 2000-2003. ==Production== In Grane oil field, [[Norsk Hydro]] used the technology applied its [[Troll_gas_field|Troll]] and [[Oseberg oil field|Oseberg]] fields to maximize production in Grane. An estimated {{convert|700|Moilbbl}} is expected to be produced by the field with {{convert|214|koilbbl/d}}. With the first horizontal well drilled, Hydro already reached a peak production by 10 March 2006 setting a record at {{convert|243|koilbbl/d}} which exceeded the initially established field plan by about {{convert|30|koilbbl}}. From then on, the field supplied the market an average {{convert|220|koilbbl/d}}. The company expects 55% recovery from the field. This makes Grane third of the size of [[Oseberg]] and twice the size of [[Brage oil field|Brage]]. There is no gas cap in Grane field. ==See also== {{Portal|Norway|Energy}} *[[Sture terminal]] *[[Heimdal gas field]] *[[Oseberg Transport System]] *[[Oseberg oil field]] *[[North Sea oil]] *[[Economy of Norway]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.statoil.com/ Statoil official website] {{Resources in Norway}} [[Category:Oil fields in Norway]] [[Category:North Sea energy]] [[Category:Energy in Europe]] [[Category:Equinor oil and gas fields]] [[Category:ExxonMobil oil and gas fields]] [[Category:ConocoPhillips oil and gas fields]]

page.title: Hero Found: The Greatest POW Escape of the Vietnam War

revision.text:
{{infobox book | | name = Hero Found: The Greatest POW Escape of the Vietnam War | title_orig = | translator = | image = Hero Found by Bruce B. Henderson (cover).jpg | caption = First-edition cover | author = [[Bruce Henderson (author)|Bruce Henderson]] | website = http://brucehendersonbooks.com/ | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = [[Non-fiction|Biography]] | publisher = [[HarperCollins]] | release_date = June 29, 2010 | media_type = [[Hardcover]]
[[Paperback#Trade paperback|Trade paperback]]
[[E-book]]
[[Audiobook]] | pages = 320 | isbn = 978-0-06-157136-7 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Hero Found: The Greatest POW Escape of the Vietnam War''''' is a [[2010 in literature|2010]] [[non-fiction]] book by author [[Bruce Henderson (author)|Bruce Henderson]]. ''Hero Found'' is a biography of [[Vietnam War]] hero [[Dieter Dengler]], a German-born [[United States Navy]] [[naval aviator]] who endured six months of imprisonment and [[torture]] before being rescued. Dengler survived 23 days in the jungle after escaping from a [[Pathet Lao]] prison camp. ==Synopsis== Dieter Dengler's survival skills are established at an early age growing up in the chaos of [[World War II]] Germany. After his father is killed in the war, his mother teaches Dieter and his brothers how to survive on their own in the forest. Dieter learns what foods are safe to eat and how to find shelter from the elements. His lifelong love of aviation begins as he observes an [[Allies of World War II|Allied]] fighter fly past at tree-top level with the pilot wearing goggles and a white scarf. At sixteen, Dieter decides to move to America to become a pilot. Surviving on his wits and with little money, Dieter sails to [[New York City]] aboard [[SS America (1939)|SS ''America'']]. He joins the U.S. Navy and becomes a naval aviator. After additional flight training, Dengler is assigned to [[VA-145 (U.S. Navy)|VA-145]] flying the [[Douglas A-1 Skyraider]] aboard {{USS|Ranger|CV-61}}. In January 1966, ''Ranger'' reaches the coast of [[Vietnam]] to conduct combat operations. On February 1, 1966, Dieter is shot down during a mission into [[Laos]] and crash-lands in a jungle clearing. A day later, he is captured by the [[Pathet Lao]]. Dieter is beaten by his captors and forced to march through the jungle for over a week. After refusing to sign papers denouncing the United States, he is beaten into unconsciousness. As the forced march continues, Dieter escapes but is recaptured and tortured. Two weeks after his crash-landing, Dieter arrives at a [[Prisoner-of-war camp|Prisoner of War (POW) camp]] having marched 85 miles. Here he meets other prisoners including [[Duane W. Martin|Dwayne Martin]], Prasit Thanee, [[Phisit Intharathat]], To Yick Chiu, and [[Eugene DeBruin]], some of whom have been imprisoned for two and a half years. The group endures illness, starvation, and brutal treatment waiting for the [[Wet season|monsoon season]] when there will be enough water to sustain them during an escape. The rains do not come on time and conditions deteriorate at the camp to a point where the guards plan to kill the prisoners and return home. On June 29, 1966, the prisoners decide to attempt their escape. A fight ensues leaving many of the guards dead. The group splits up with Dieter and Dwayne marching into the forest toward [[Thailand]]. The monsoon rains start, but the pair are soon lost and gradually weaken as they struggle through the jungle. They surprise a villager who [[Decapitation|decapitates]] Dwayne with a [[machete]]. Dieter is pursued by the villagers and Pathet Lao but manages to avoid them. He continues to weaken and begins to [[hallucinate]]. Near the end of his strength, Dieter rests on a rock and sees a [[United States Air Force]] Skyraider flying towards him. Dieter signals the aircraft and is spotted by the pilot, [[Eugene Peyton Deatrick|Eugene Deatrick]], who persists in calling a rescue despite the possibility that this could be a trap. On July 20, 1966, Dieter is finally rescued from his ordeal after 23 days in the jungle and six months after he was shot down. Dieter is reunited with his comrades on ''Ranger'' and begins the long recovery to health. His story of survival and endurance is widely reported in the press and celebrated by the U.S. government. Dieter is awarded the [[Navy Cross]] for extraordinary heroism. He leaves military service and enjoys the life he so nearly lost. In 2000, Dieter is diagnosed with [[amyotrophic lateral sclerosis]] and gradually loses his mobility and ability to speak. Dieter tells his wife that the disease is worse than the prison camp in Laos. On February 7, 2001, Dieter commits suicide to escape from a disease that would cage him in his own body. In March 2001, Dieter is buried in [[Arlington National Cemetery]] with full military honors. ==Reviews== ''Hero Found'' received positive reviews. ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]'' called the book "a short but engaging tale of a harrowing POW experience."{{cite web | url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/bruce-henderson/hero-found/ | title=Hero Found: The Greatest POW Escape of the Vietnam War | publisher=[[Kirkus Reviews]] | date=January 19, 2011 | accessdate=January 31, 2015}} ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' stated "This often riveting account sheds new light on an oft-told true story."{{cite web |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-06-157136-7#path/978-0-06-157136-7 |title=Hero Found: The Greatest POW Escape of the Vietnam War |work=[[Publishers Weekly]] |author= |date=April 26, 2010 |accessdate=January 31, 2015}} ''[[AudioFile (magazine)|Audiofile]]'' observed "Narrator Todd McLaren delivers the many scenes of aerial action and combat with enthusiasm and excitement. His animated involvement adds a special spark to a work already compelling from beginning to end."{{cite web |url=http://www.audiofilemagazine.com/reviews/read/57170/ |title=Hero Found: The Greatest POW Escape of the Vietnam War |work=[[AudioFile (magazine)|Audiofile]] |author= | date=September 2010 |accessdate=March 1, 2015}} ==Release details== ''Hero Found'' was released in [[hardcover]], [[paperback]], [[e-book]], and [[audiobook]] editions: * {{cite book |last=Henderson |first=Bruce |authorlink=Bruce Henderson (author) | title= Hero Found: The Greatest POW Escape of the Vietnam War | publisher=[[HarperCollins]] | year=2010 | isbn=978-0-06-157136-7 | pages=320 |edition=Hard cover }} * {{cite book |last=Henderson |first=Bruce |authorlink=Bruce Henderson (author) | title= Hero Found: The Greatest POW Escape of the Vietnam War | publisher=[[HarperCollins]] | year=2011 | isbn=978-0061571374 | pages=336 |edition=Paperback}} * {{cite book |last=Henderson |first=Bruce |authorlink=Bruce Henderson (author) | title= Hero Found: The Greatest POW Escape of the Vietnam War | publisher=[[HarperCollins]] | year=2010 | isbn=0061571369| pages=332 |edition=eBook}} * {{cite AV media |last1=Henderson |first1=Bruce (author) |authorlink1=Bruce Henderson (author) |last2=McLaren |first2=Todd (narrator) | title=Hero Found: The Greatest POW Escape of the Vietnam War | publisher=[[Tantor Audio]] | year=2010 | isbn=978-1400147021| pages= |edition=Audiobook}} ==See also== * [[Nigel Cawthorne#Prisoner of War series|''The Bamboo Cage'']]—a book on Vietnam War POWs and MIAs that covers Dengler * ''[[Little Dieter Needs to Fly]]''—a 1997 [[documentary film]] about Dengler, written and directed by [[Werner Herzog]] * ''[[Rescue Dawn]]''—a 2006 [[War film|war]] [[drama film]] about Dengler, directed by Werner Herzog, based on ''Little Dieter Needs to Fly'' ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{cite web |title=Bruce Henderson: "Hero Found" |url=http://thedianerehmshow.org/shows/2010-06-29/bruce-henderson-hero-found |work=[[The Diane Rehm Show]] |author= |date=April 26, 2010 |accessdate=January 31, 2015}} * {{cite web |last=Henderson |first=Bruce |authorlink=Bruce Henderson (author) |title=Dieter Dengler's Great Escape from Laotian POW Camp |url=http://www.historynet.com/dieter-denglers-great-escape-from-laotian-pow-camp.htm |work=HistoryNet.com |date=July 12, 2010 |accessdate=January 31, 2015}} [[Category:2010 non-fiction books]] [[Category:Biographies (books)]] [[Category:Books about survival]] [[Category:HarperCollins books]] [[Category:Vietnam War books]]

revision.comment: /* Life */Improving links and other minor cleanup tasks
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox scientist |name = John Richardson |image = Sir John Richardson.jpg |image_size = 230px |caption = |birth_date = 5 November 1787 |birth_place = [[Dumfries]] |death_date = {{d-da|5 June 1865|5 November 1787}} |death_place = [[Lake District]] |residence = [[Lake District]] |citizenship = British |nationality = [[Scotland|Scottish]] |ethnicity = Scottish |field = [[surgery|surgeon]]
[[natural history|naturalist]] |work_institutions = |alma_mater = [[Edinburgh University]] |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = |author_abbrev_bot = Richardson |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |prizes = [[Royal Medal]] {{small|(1856)}} |religion = Anglican |footnotes = |signature = }} [[File:John Richardson b1787.jpg|thumb|John Richardson, 1828 by [[Thomas Phillips]], R.A., engraved by [[Edward Finden]]]] '''Sir John Richardson''' [[Royal Society of London|FRS]] [[FRSE]] FLS FGS MWS LLD (5 November 1787 – 5 June 1865) was a [[Scotland|Scottish]] [[ship's doctor|naval surgeon]], [[natural history|naturalist]] and [[arctic]] [[explorer]].{{cite web |url=http://www.biographi.ca/009004-119.01-e.php?&id_nbr=4670 |title=Biography at the ''Dictionary of Canadian Biography Online'' |publisher=Library and Archive Canada |accessdate=19 June 2008}} ==Life== Richardson was born at Nith Place in [[Dumfries]] the son of Gabriel Richardson, Provost of Dumfries, and his wife, Anne Mundell. He was educated at Dumfries Grammar School. He was then apprenticed to his maternal uncle, Dr James Mundell, a surgeon in Dumfries.{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp2.pdf}} He studied [[medicine]] at [[Edinburgh University]], and became a surgeon in the navy in 1807. He traveled with [[John Franklin]] in search of the [[Northwest Passage]] on the [[Coppermine Expedition of 1819–1822]]. Richardson wrote the sections on [[geology]], [[botany]] and [[ichthyology]] for the official account of the expedition. Franklin and Richardson returned to Canada in 1825 and went overland by fur trade routes to the mouth of the [[Mackenzie River]]. Franklin was to go as far west as possible and Richardson was to go east to the mouth of the [[Coppermine River]]. These were the only known points on the central coast and had been reached in 1793 and 1771 respectively. He had with him two specially-built boats which were more ocean-worthy than the voyageur canoes used by Franklin on his previous expedition. They gave their names to the [[Dolphin and Union Strait]] near the end of his route. His journey was successful and he reached his furthest east the same day that Franklin reached his furthest west (16 August 1826). He abandoned his boats at [[Bloody Falls]] and trekked overland to [[Deline|Fort Franklin]] which he reached three weeks before Franklin. Together they had surveyed 1,878 miles of previously unmapped coast. The natural history discoveries of this expedition were so great that they had to be recorded in two separate works, the ''Flora Boreali-Americana'' (1833–40), written by [[William Jackson Hooker]], and the ''Fauna Boreali-Americana'' (1829–37), written by Richardson, [[William John Swainson]], [[John Edward Gray]] and [[William Kirby (entomologist)|William Kirby]]. At the [[British Association for the Advancement of Science]] meeting in 1842, Richardson described the [[Standard diving dress|diving apparatus]] and treatment of diver Roderick Cameron following an injury that occurred on 14 October 1841 during the salvage operations on {{HMS|Royal George|1756|6}}.{{cite journal |author=Richardson J |title=Abstract of the case of a diver employed on the wreck of the Royal George, who was injured by the bursting of the air-pipe of the diving apparatus. 1842 |journal=Undersea Biomed Res |volume=18 |issue=1 |pages=63–4 |date=January 1991 |pmid=2021022 |doi= |url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/2729 |accessdate=19 June 2008}} Richardson was knighted by [[Queen Victoria]] in 1846. He traveled with [[John Rae (explorer)|John Rae]] on an [[Rae–Richardson Arctic Expedition|unsuccessful search]] for Franklin in 1848–49, describing it in ''An Arctic Searching Expedition'' (1851). He retired to the [[Lake District]] in 1855. He died at his home Lancrigg House north of [[Grasmere (village)|Grasmere]] on 5 June 1865, and is buried at [[St Oswald's Church, Grasmere]]. ==Family== He married three times: firstly in 1818 to Mary Stiven; secondly in 1833 to Mary Booth; and finally in 1847 to Mary Fletcher.{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp2.pdf}} ==Works== He also wrote accounts dealing with the natural history, and especially the ichthyology, of several other Arctic voyages, and was the author of ''Icones Piscium'' (1843), ''Catalogue of Apodal Fish in the British Museum'' (1856), the second edition of [[William Yarrell|Yarrell]]'s ''History of British Fishes'' (1860), ''The Polar Regions'' (1861). and ''Arctic Ordeal: The Journal of John Richardson'' Edited by C. Stuart Houston (1984). The National Marine Biological Library at the [[Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom|Marine Biological Association]] retains some original illustrations used by Richardson in preparation for the second edition of Yarrell's book.Richardon material in the [[Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom|MBA]] Archive Collection: http://www.mba.ac.uk/NMBL/archives/archives_personal/personal_papers.htm#richard ==Eponyms== Richardson is commemorated in the [[Binomial nomenclature|scientific names]] of four [[species]] of reptiles: ''[[Eremiascincus|Eremiascincus richardsonii]], [[Hemidactylus|Hemidactylus richardsonii]], [[Myron richardsonii]]'', and ''[[Sphaerodactylus|Sphaerodactylus richardsonii]]''.Beolens B, Watkins M, Grayson M (2011). ''The Eponym Dictionary of Reptiles''. Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press. xiii + 296 pp. {{ISBN|978-1-4214-0135-5}}. ("Richardson", pp. 220-221). == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Gutenberg author | id=Richardson,+John | name=John Richardson}} * {{FadedPage|id=Richardson, Sir John|name=John Richardson|author=yes}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Sir John Richardson |birth=1787 |death=1865 }} *[http://www.aina.ucalgary.ca/scripts/minisa.dll/144/proe/proarc/se+arctic,+v.+36,+no.++4,+Dec.+1983,*?COMMANDSEARCH '' Houston, C.S. page.title: List of Lepidoptera that feed on roses

revision.text:
'''[[Rose]]s''' (''Rosa'' species) are used as food plants by the [[caterpillar]]s ([[larva]]e) of a number of [[Lepidoptera]] species, including:
==[[phagy|Monophagous]]== Species that feed exclusively on ''Rosa''
[[File:Coleophora gryphipennella mined rose leaf with a case attached.JPG|thumb|''[[Coleophora gryphipennella]]'' case on a rose leaf]] * [[Coleophoridae]] ** Several ''[[Coleophora]]'' case-bearer species: *** [[Coleophora gryphipennella|''C. gryphipennella'']] *** [[Coleophora rosacella|''C. rosacella'']] *** [[Coleophora rosaefoliella|''C. rosaefoliella'']]
==[[phagy|Polyphagous]]== Species that feed on ''Rosa'' and other plants
* [[Arctiidae]] ** ''[[Hypercompe indecisa]]'' * [[Coleophoridae]] ** Several ''[[Coleophora]]'' case-bearer species: *** ''[[Coleophora paripennella|C. paripennella]]'' *** ''[[Coleophora potentillae|C. potentillae]]'' * [[Geometridae]] ** [[Common emerald]] (''Hemithea aestivaria'') ** [[Common marbled carpet]] (''Chloroclysta truncata'') ** [[Double-striped pug]] (''Gymnoscelis rufifasciata'') ** [[Engrailed (moth)|Engrailed]] (''Ectropis crepuscularia'') ** [[Mottled umber]] (''Erannis defoliaria'') ** [[Purple thorn]] (''Selenia tetralunaria'') ** [[Scalloped oak]] (''Crocallis elinguaria'') ** [[Winter moth]] (''Operophtera brumata'') * [[Hepialidae]] ** ''[[Endoclita malabaricus]]'' * [[Hesperiidae]] ** [[Grizzled skipper]] (''Pyrgus malvae'') * [[Lymantriidae]] ** [[Brown-tail]] (''Euproctis chrysorrhoea'') * [[Noctuidae]] ** [[Copper underwing]] (''Amphipyra pyramidea'') ** [[Dark dagger]] (''Acronicta tridens'') ** [[Grey dagger]] (''Acronicta psi'') ** [[Mouse moth]] (''Amphipyra tragopoginis'') * [[Notodontidae]] ** [[Buff-tip]] (''Phalera bucephala'') ** [[Coxcomb prominent]] (''Ptilodon capucina'') ** [[Rough prominent]] (''Nadata gibbosa'') * [[Saturniidae]] ** [[Emperor moth]] (''Pavonia pavonia'')
==External links== *[http://www.nhm.ac.uk/our-science/data/hostplants/search/list.dsml?searchPageURL=index.dsml&PGenus=Rosa&sort=Taxon "Search Results - Hostplant Genus: ''Rosa''"] at ''HOSTS - a Database of the World's Lepidopteran Hostplants'' of the Natural History Museum, London. Retrieved 8 October 2017.
[[Category:Lists of Lepidoptera by food|Roses]] [[Category:Roses]]

page.title: List of Lepidoptera that feed on spruces

revision.comment: Lower case for species common names as described at [[MOS:LIFE]] - also some copy editing using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''[[Spruce]]s''', ''Picea'' species, are used as food plants by the [[caterpillar]]s of many species of [[Lepidoptera]]. The Database of the World's Lepidopteran Hostplants (HOSTS) lists over 1,000 species of Lepidoptera (See External links).
A few examples are listed below:
* [[Batrachedridae]] ** ''[[Batrachedra pinicolella]]'' * [[Gelechiidae]] **''[[Chionodes]]'' species: *** ''[[Chionodes continuella|C. continuella]]'' – recorded on [[white spruce]] (''P. glauca'') *** ''[[Chionodes electella|C. electella]]'' * [[Geometridae]] ** ''[[Bupalus piniaria]]'' (bordered white) ** ''[[Ectropis crepuscularia]]'' (engrailed) ** ''[[Epirrita autumnata]]'' (autumnal moth) ** ''[[Eupithecia subfuscata]]'' (grey pug) – recorded on [[black spruce]] (''P. mariana'') ** ''[[Odontopera bidentata]]'' (scalloped hazel) – recorded on [[Norway spruce]] (''P. abies'') ** ''[[Operophtera brumata]]'' (winter moth) – recorded on Norway spruce (''P. abies'') * [[Hepialidae]] ** ''[[Gazoryctra wielgusi]]'' ** ''[[Korscheltellus gracilis]]'' (conifer swift) – prefers [[red spruce]] (''P. rubens''), also recorded on white spruce (''P. glauca'') * [[Lymantriidae]] ** ''[[Lymantria dispar]]'' (gypsy moth) – older larvae only * [[Noctuidae]] ** ''[[Agrotis segetum]]'' (turnip moth) – recorded on [[Sitka spruce]] (''P. sitchensis'') ** ''[[Panolis flammea]]'' (pine beauty) * [[Tortricidae]] ** ''[[Cydia duplicana]]'' – recorded on injured bark of Norway spruce (''P. abies'') ** ''[[Cydia illutana]]'' – recorded on Norway spruce (''P. abies'') and [[Siberian spruce]] (''P.'' (''a.'') ''obovata'') cone scales ** ''[[Syndemis musculana]]''
==External links== *[http://www.nhm.ac.uk/our-science/data/hostplants/search/list.dsml?searchPageURL=index.dsml&PGenus=Picea&sort=Family "Search Results - Hostplant Genus: ''Picea''"] at ''HOSTS - a Database of the World's Lepidopteran Hostplants'' of the Natural History Museum, London. Retrieved 9 October 2017.
[[Category:Lists of Lepidoptera by food|Spruce]] [[Category:Picea|+Lepidoptera]]

revision.comment: /* Flooded grasslands and savannas */ Updated name of PA0907
revision.text:
The following is a list of [[ecoregion]]s in [[Russia]], according to the [[Worldwide Fund for Nature]] (WWF):
==Terrestrial== ===[[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forests]]===
*[[Caucasus mixed forests]] ([[Armenia]], [[Azerbaijan]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Russia]], [[Turkey]]) *[[Central European mixed forests]] ([[Austria]], [[Belarus]], [[Czech Republic]], [[Germany]], [[Lithuania]], [[Moldova]], [[Poland]], [[Romania]], [[Russia]], [[Ukraine]]) *[[Crimean Submediterranean forest complex]] ([[Russia]], [[Ukraine]]) *[[East European forest steppe]] ([[Bulgaria]], [[Moldova]], [[Romania]], [[Russia]], [[Ukraine]]) *[[Sarmatic mixed forests]] ([[Belarus]], [[Estonia]], [[Finland]], [[Latvia]], [[Lithuania]], [[Norway]], [[Russia]], [[Sweden]]) *[[South Sakhalin-Kurile mixed forests]] ([[Russia]]) *[[Ussuri broadleaf and mixed forests]] ([[Russia]]) *[[West Siberian broadleaf and mixed forests]] ([[Russia]])
===[[Temperate coniferous forests]]===
*[[Altai montane forest and forest steppe]] ([[China]], [[Kazakhstan]], [[Mongolia]], [[Russia]]) *[[Da Hinggan-Dzhagdy Mountains conifer forests]] ([[China]], [[Russia]]) *[[Sayan montane conifer forests]] ([[Mongolia]], [[Russia]])
===[[Boreal forests/taiga]]===
*[[East Siberian taiga]] ([[Russia]]) *[[Kamchatka-Kurile meadows and sparse forests]] ([[Russia]]) *[[Kamchatka-Kurile taiga]] ([[Russia]]) *[[Northeast Siberian taiga]] ([[Russia]]) *[[Okhotsk-Manchurian taiga]] ([[Russia]]) *[[Sakhalin Island taiga]] ([[Russia]]) *[[Scandinavian and Russian taiga]] ([[Finland]], [[Norway]], [[Russia]], [[Sweden]]) *[[Trans-Baikal conifer forests]] ([[Mongolia]], [[Russia]]) *[[Urals montane tundra and taiga]] ([[Russia]]) *[[West Siberian taiga]] ([[Russia]])
===[[Temperate grasslands, savannas and shrublands]]===
*[[Daurian forest steppe]] ([[China]], [[Mongolia]], [[Russia]]) *[[Kazakh forest steppe]] ([[Kazakhstan]], [[Russia]]) *[[Kazakh steppe]] ([[Kazakhstan]], [[Russia]]) *[[Mongolian-Manchurian grassland]] ([[China]], [[Mongolia]], [[Russia]]) *[[Pontic steppe]] ([[Moldova]], [[Romania]], [[Russia]], [[Ukraine]]) *[[Sayan Intermontane steppe]] ([[Russia]]) *[[Selenge-Orkhon forest steppe]] ([[Mongolia]], [[Russia]]) *[[South Siberian forest steppe]] ([[Russia]])
===[[Flooded grasslands and savannas]]===
*[[Amur meadow steppe]] ([[China]], [[Russia]]) *[[Suiphun-Khanka meadows and forest meadows]] ([[Russia]], [[China]])
===[[Montane grasslands and shrublands]]===
*[[Altai alpine meadow and tundra]] ([[China]], [[Kazakhstan]], [[Mongolia]], [[Russia]]) *[[Sayan Alpine meadows and tundra]] ([[Mongolia]], [[Russia]])
===[[Tundra]]===
*[[Arctic desert]] ([[Russia]]) *[[Bering tundra]] ([[Russia]]) *[[Cherskii-Kolyma mountain tundra]] ([[Russia]]) *[[Chukchi Peninsula tundra]] ([[Russia]]) *[[Kamchatka Mountain tundra and forest tundra]] ([[Russia]]) *[[Kola Peninsula tundra]] ([[Norway]], [[Russia]]) *[[Northeast Siberian coastal tundra]] ([[Russia]]) *[[Northwest Russian-Novaya Zemlya tundra]] ([[Russia]]) *[[Novosibirsk Islands arctic desert]] ([[Russia]]) *[[Taimyr-Central Siberian tundra]] ([[Russia]]) *[[Trans-Baikal Bald Mountain tundra]] ([[Russia]]) *[[Wrangel Island arctic desert]] ([[Russia]]) *[[Yamalagydanskaja tundra]] ([[Russia]])
===[[Deserts and xeric shrublands]]===
*[[Caspian lowland desert]] ([[Iran]], [[Kazakhstan]], [[Russia]], [[Turkmenistan]]) *[[Great Lakes Basin desert steppe]] ([[Mongolia]], [[Russia]])
==Freshwater==
{{Empty section|date=July 2010}} ==Marine== (by [[marine realm|realm]] and [[marine province|province]]) ===[[Arctic realm]]=== (no provinces identified)
*[[Beaufort Sea-continental coast and shelf]] *[[Chukchi Sea]] *[[Eastern Bering Sea]] *[[East Siberian Sea]] *[[Laptev Sea]] *[[Kara Sea]] *[[North and East Barents Sea]] *[[White Sea]]
===Temperate Northern Atlantic=== ====[[Northern European Seas]]==== *[[Northern Norway and Finnmark]] *[[Baltic Sea]]
===[[Temperate Northern Pacific]]=== ====[[Cold Temperate Northwest Pacific]]==== *[[Sea of Okhotsk]] *[[Kamchatka Shelf and Coast]] *[[Northern Honshu]] *[[Sea of Japan]]
====[[Cold Temperate Northeast Pacific]]==== *[[Aleutian Islands]]

page.title: List of invasive species in Australia

revision.comment: /* Mammals */ Most pages on mammals are at their common names. Also, there are several dedicated pages on the impact of specific feral species in Australia.
revision.text:
{{Main|Invasive species in Australia}} This is a list of some of the more notable [[invasive species]] in [[Australia]]. {{TOC right}}
==Species==
===Plants=== :''The Australian Weeds Committee maintain a [[noxious weed]]s list covering all the states and territories.''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.weeds.org.au/docs/weednet6.pdf |title=Noxious Weed List for Australian States and Territories |date=June 2012 |publisher=Australian Weeds Committee |accessdate=17 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070830083549/http://www.weeds.org.au/docs/weednet6.pdf |archivedate=30 August 2007 |df= }}</ref>
* ''[[Acacia farnesiana]]'' (Sweet acacia)<ref>[http://www.hear.org/pier/species/acacia_farnesiana.htm ''Acacia farnesiana '']. Pacific Island Ecosystems at Risk. Retrieved on 2009-04-09.</ref> * ''[[Ailanthus altissima]]'' (Tree of heaven)<ref name="ausweeds">[http://www.weeds.org.au/docs/weednet6.pdf Noxious weed list for Australian states and territories] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070830083549/http://www.weeds.org.au/docs/weednet6.pdf |date=2007-08-30 }}. Australian Weeds Committee, September 2005. Retrieved on 2008-12-01.</ref> * ''[[Alternanthera philoxeroides]]'' (Alligator weed)<ref name="ausweeds" /> * ''[[Andropogon virginicus]]'' (Broomsedge)<ref>[http://www.issg.org/database/species/distribution.asp?si=200&fr=1&sts=tss&lang=EN ''Andropogon virginicus'' alien range]. Global Invasive Species Database. Retrieved on 2009-04-09.</ref> * ''[[Annona glabra]]'' (Alligator apple)<ref name="ausweeds" /> * ''[[Anredera cordifolia]]'' (Madeira vine)<ref name="ausweeds" /> * ''[[Ardisia elliptica]]'' (Shoebutton Ardisia)<ref>[http://www.issg.org/database/species/distribution.asp?si=52&fr=1&sts=tss&lang=EN ''Ardisia elliptica'' alien range]. Global Invasive Species Database. Retrieved on 2009-04-09.</ref> * ''[[Arundo donax]]'' (Giant cane)<ref name="ausweeds" /> * ''[[Asparagus aethiopicus]]'' (Asparagus fern)<ref name="ausweeds" /> * ''[[Berberis thunbergii]]'' (Japanese barberry)<ref name="berberis">[http://www.issg.org/database/species/distribution.asp?si=592&fr=1&sts=tss&lang=EN ''Berberis thunbergii'' alien range]. Global Invasive Species Database. Retrieved on 2009-04-09.</ref> * ''[[Brassica tournefortii]]'' (African mustard)<ref>[http://www.issg.org/database/species/distribution.asp?si=819&fr=1&sts=tss&lang=EN ''Brassica tournefortii'' alien range]. Global Invasive Species Database. Retrieved on 2009-04-09.</ref> * ''[[Bromus rubens]]'' (Foxtail brome)<ref>[http://www.issg.org/database/species/distribution.asp?si=596&fr=1&sts=tss&lang=EN ''Bromus rubens'' alien range]. Global Invasive Species Database. Retrieved on 2009-04-09.</ref> * ''[[Chrysanthemoides monilifera]]'' (Bitou bush)<ref name="ausweeds" /> * ''[[Cinnamomum camphora]]'' (Camphor laurel)<ref name="ausweeds" /> * ''[[Cryptostegia grandiflora]]'' (rubber vine)<ref>[http://www.daff.qld.gov.au/documents/Biosecurity_EnvironmentalPests/IPA-RubberVine-PSA.pdf Rubber vine in Queensland]</ref> * ''[[Echium plantagineum]]'' (Paterson's curse)<ref name="ausweeds" /> * ''[[Hypericum perforatum]]'' (St. John's wort)<ref>[http://www.sgaonline.org.au/invasive_hypericumperforatum.html Invasive Plants]. Sustainable Gardening Australia. Retrieved on 2009-05-20.</ref> * ''[[Lantana camara]]'' (Lantana)<ref name="ausweeds" /> * ''[[Opuntia]]'' spp. ([[Prickly pears in Australia|Prickly pear]])<ref name="ausweeds" /> * ''[[Solanum mauritianum]]'' (Wild tobacco)<ref name="ausweeds" />
===Animals===
====Arthropods==== * ''[[Amphibalanus improvisus]]'' (bay barnacle) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/91903] * ''[[Carcinus maenas]]'' (shore crab) * ''[[Cherax destructor]]'' (common yabby) * ''Limnoria quadripunctata'' (gribble) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/109147]
=====Insects=====
* ''[[Bemisia tabaci]]'' (Silverleaf whitefly)<ref>[http://www.padil.gov.au/viewPestDistribution.aspx?id=290 Cotton whitefly distribution]. Pests and Diseases Image Library. Retrieved on 2009-04-09.</ref> * ''[[Solenopsis invicta]]'' (Red imported fire ant)<ref>[http://www.issg.org/database/species/distribution.asp?si=77&fr=1&sts=tss&lang=EN ''Solenopsis invicta'' alien range]. Global Invasive Species Database. Retrieved on 2009-04-09.</ref> * ''[[Vespula germanica]]'' (European wasp)<ref>http://digital.library.adelaide.edu.au/dspace/handle/2440/22127</ref> * ''[[Pharaoh Ant|Monomorium pharaonis]]'' (Pharaoh ant)<ref name="Pharaoh Ant">{{cite journal|last=Anderson|first=Alan|author2=M. Blum |author3=T. Jones |title=Venom Alkaloids in Monomorium "rothsteini" Forel Repel Other Ants: Is This the Secret to Success by Monomorium in Australian Ant Communities?|journal=Oecologia|date=16 June 1991|volume=88|issue=2|pages=157–160|doi=10.1007/bf00320805|jstor=4219770}}</ref> * ''[[Longhorn crazy ant|Paratrechina Longicornis]]'' (Longhorn crazy ant)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longhorn_crazy_ant|title=Black crazy ant is described as an agricultural and domestic pest.|last=|first=|date=|website=Wikipedia.org|access-date=}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=November 2017}} * ''[[Yellow crazy ant|Anoplolepis gracilipes]]'' (Yellow crazy ant)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yellow_crazy_ant|title=Has been found in northern and western Australia as well on the Christmas Island.|last=|first=|date=|website=Wikipedia.org|access-date=}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=November 2017}} * ''[[Apis cerana|Apis Cerana]]'' (Eastern Honey Bee)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apis_cerana#cite_note-12|title="[...]with particular concern about its invasive potential in Australia as nests are found in a variety of environments, including both natural and man-made"|last=|first=|date=|website=Wikipedia.org|access-date=}}</ref> * ''[[Aedes albopictus]]'' (tiger mosquito) * ''[[Aethina tumida]]'' (small hive beetle) * ''[[Aphis spiraecola]]'' (green citrus aphid) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/6221] * ''[[Bactrocera cucurbitae]]'' (melon fly) * ''Bruchophagus roddi'' (alfalfa seed chalcid) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/10083] * ''Cerataphis lataniae'' (palm aphid) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/16743] * ''[[Ceratitis capitata]]'' (Mediterranean fruit fly) [https://www.agric.wa.gov.au/fruit/mediterranean-fruit-fly?nopaging=1] * ''[[Corythucha ciliata]]'' (sycamore lace bug) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/16264] * ''[[Cryptotermes brevis]]'' (West Indian drywood termite) * ''[[Diuraphis noxia]]'' (Russian wheat aphid) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/9887] * ''[[Forficula auricularia]]'' (common earwig) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/24345] * ''[[Frankliniella occidentalis]]'' (western flower thrips) * ''Hylurgus ligniperda'' (red-haired pine bark beetle) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/27364] * ''Idioscopus nitidulus'' (mango leafhopper) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/28472] * ''[[Linepithema humile]]'' (Argentine ant) * ''[[Maconellicoccus hirsutus]]'' (hibiscus mealybug) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/40171] * ''[[Pheidole megacephala]]'' (coastal brown ant) * ''Phylacteophaga froggatti'' (leafblister sawfly) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/40283] * ''Pineus pini'' (pine adelgid) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/41326] * ''[[Sitobion miscanthi]]'' (Indian grain aphid) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/51740] * ''Solenopsis geminata'' (ginger ant) [https://dpir.nt.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0016/228121/ent220ants20in20the20household20and20garden20factsheet.pdf] * ''[[Spodoptera litura]]'' (Oriental leafworm moth) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/44520] * ''[[Tapinoma melanocephalum]]'' (ghost ant) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/54310] * ''[[Tremex fuscicornis]]'' (tremex wasp) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/54516] * ''[[Trichomyrmex destructor]]'' (destructive trailing ant) * ''[[Vespula vulgaris]]'' (common wasp) * ''[[Wasmannia auropunctata]]'' (electric ant) * ''[[Xanthogaleruca luteola]]'' (elm-leaf beetle) * ''Xyleborinus saxesenii'' (fruit-tree pinhole borer) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/57038]
====Molluscs==== [[Image:Kadina-snails-climb-fence-0717.jpg|thumb|Native to the Mediterranean regions, more than one species of white snail is now quite common in [[Kadina, South Australia|Kadina]] and elsewhere in [[South Australia]]. This image shows many ''Theba pisana'', and a number of smaller and more pointed ''Cochlicella acuta'' aestivating on a fence post.]] * ''[[Cernuella virgata]]'' (Common white snail)<ref>[http://www.dpiw.tas.gov.au/inter.nsf/Attachments/LBUN-74L3NM/$FILE/white%20snails%20C%20virgata%20Fact%20Sheet.pdf Common white snail or Mediterranean white snail]</ref> * ''[[Cochlicella acuta]]'' (Pointed snail)<ref>[http://www.publish.csiro.au/?paper=EA08031 The population dynamics of the mediterranean snails Cernuella virgata, Cochlicella acuta (Hygromiidae) and Theba pisana (Helicidae) in pasture–cereal rotations in South Australia]. (Abstract). CSIRO Publishing. Retrieved on 2009-04-09.</ref> * ''[[Cochlicella barbara]]'' (Small pointed snail)<ref>Helicidae and Hygromiidae as Pests in Cereal Crops and Pastures in Southern Australia. In Baker, G.M. [https://books.google.com/books?id=cic8VNOWMnQC ''Molluscs as Crop Pests''] CABI, 2002.. p.193.</ref> * ''[[Cornu aspersum]]'' (garden snail) * ''[[Deroceras invadens]]'' (tramp slug) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/121099] * ''[[Deroceras laeve]]'' (marsh slug) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/85751] * ''[[Magallana gigas]]'' (Pacific oyster) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/87296] * ''[[Musculista senhousia]]'' (Asian mussel)<ref>[http://www.marine.csiro.au/crimp/nimpis/spSummary.asp?txa=6146 ''Musculista senhousia'' species summary]. National Introduced Marine Pest Information System. Retrieved on 2009-04-09.</ref> * ''[[Theba pisana]]'' (White garden snail)<ref>[http://www.pestalert.org/viewArchPestAlert.cfm?rid=52]</ref>
===Chordates===

Retrieved on 2008-12-04.</ref> * ''[[Rainbow trout|Oncorhynchus mykiss]]'' (Rainbow trout)<ref name="trout">[http://www.issg.org/database/species/distribution.asp?si=103&fr=1&sts=tss&lang=EN ''Oncorhynchus mykiss'' alien range]. Retrieved on 2009-04-09.</ref> * ''[[Oreochromis]]'' spp. ([[Tilapia as exotic species|Tilapia]])<ref>[http://www.invasiveanimals.com/invasive-animals/fish/tilapia/index.html Economic and environmental impacts caused by tilapia]. Retrieved on 2008-12-04.</ref> * ''[[Pelmatolapia mariae]]'' (spotted tilapia) * ''[[Perca fluviatilis]]'' (European perch, redfin perch)<ref>[http://www.issg.org/database/species/distribution.asp?si=548&fr=1&sts=tss&lang=EN ''Perca fluviatilis'' alien range]. Retrieved on 2009-04-09.</ref> * ''[[Salmo trutta]]'' (Brown trout)<ref>[http://www.issg.org/database/species/distribution.asp?si=78&fr=1&sts=tss&lang=EN ''Salmo trutta'' alien range]. Global Invasive Species Database. Retrieved on 2009-04-09.</ref> * ''[[Xiphophorus hellerii]]'' (green swordtail) [http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/59752]
=====Reptiles & Amphibians===== * ''[[Bufo marinus]]'' (Cane toad)<ref name="CRC" /><ref>[http://www.environment.gov.au/biodiversity/invasive/publications/cane-toad/ The feral cane toad]. page.title: List of mountains of the Alps (2000–2499 m)

revision.text:
{{GeoGroupTemplate}} This page contains a table listing by [[elevation]], [[mountains]] of the [[Alps]] that are between 2000 and 2499 metres high and have a [[topographic prominence]] of at least {{convert|300|m|ft|0}}. The list is a continuation of the [[List of mountains of the Alps (2500-2999 m)]] and [[List of mountains of the Alps above 3000 m]], which page contains an introduction with statistics and an explanation of the criteria. ==Mountains of the Alps between 2000 and 2500 m== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: center; background-color:#ffffff font-size: 90%;" |- bgcolor="#dddddd" !Rank
Unranked summits have a topographic prominence between 293 and 299 m l. They are included given the uncertainties in estimating these values. !Mountain !Height
(m)All mountain heights and prominences are from the following maps:
For France the 1:25,000 [http://www.geoportail.gouv.fr/accueil cartes topographiques] of the [[Institut Géographique National]]
For Switzerland the 1:25,000 [http://map.geo.admin.ch/ Swisstopo] maps.
For Austria [[Bundesamt für Eich- und Vermessungswesen|BEV]]'s [http://www.austrianmap.at Österreichische Karte 1:50.000] supplemented with the 1:25,000 [[Alpine Club map]]s where available.
For Italy the 1:25,000 [[Istituto Geografico Militare]] maps via the [http://www.pcn.minambiente.it/viewer/ Geoportale Nazionale] website.
For Slovenia the highest scale maps available via the [http://www.geopedia.si Geopedia.si] site.
Key cols were verified using the [[SRTM]] data based contour lines in the terrain view of [[Google maps]]. ![[Topographic prominence|Drop]] (m)
Numbers in italics are estimates when a precise height for the key col is lacking. For example, maps often provide heights for the place where a route passes over a ridge rather than for the lowest point in the ridge. !CoordinatesVerified and fine-tuned via [https://maps.google.com/maps google terrain and satellite maps] !Range For the Eastern Alps the range names are according to the [[Alpine Club classification of the Eastern Alps]] !Range[[SOIUSA]] codes, representing a proposal for a new classification system of the Alps. The codes usually but not always correspond to established ranges. Sorting on this tab puts the mountains in a geographic order, roughly from the southwest to the east. !Region [[Bundesländer|State]] in Austria and Germany, [[Departments of France|department]] in France, [[Provinces of Italy|province]] in Italy, and [[Canton (country subdivision)|canton]] in Switzerland !Country |- |1052 |[[Marchkopf]] |2499 |372 |{{Coord|47|15|04|N|11|48|22|E|name=1052. This is a '''list of rivers in Israel'''. This list is arranged by drainage basin, with respective tributaries indented under each larger stream's name.

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=February 2009}}
The '''Longana''' is a legendary aquatic creature of the [[feminine]] gender. The Longana appear in legends of the people living in [[Cadore]], Italy. According to the legend, these creatures live in groups, either in coves or near cliffs.
They are similar to legends like that of the [[Faun]] as they have inferior limbs of [[goats]]. They are also depicted as [[intelligent]] and [[Beauty|beautiful]] [[women]], and they regularly converse with [[spirits]], which explains their extraordinary knowledge of natural events.
One myth tells how one of the Longana women had decided to intermix with a man, and they eventually married each other, only on the condition that the man had to totally forget the woman's origins. Eventually, the couple prosper as the woman had somehow interfered with their farming work and had made their grain aplenty. She had children and, as a result, men started calling the woman names, so she ran away leaving her husband and her children.
[[Category:Italian legendary creatures]] [[Category:Female legendary creatures]] [[Category:Mythic aquatic creatures]] [[Category:Water spirits]]
{{legendary-creature-stub}}
[[pl:Longana]] [[ru:Лонгана]]

'''Marpol Annex I''' is the first implementation made by [[MARPOL 73/78|Marpol 73/78]],<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Chronology & Search|url = http://www.martinottaway.com/technical-documents/MAX1-Studies/chronology|website = MAX1 Studies|accessdate = 2015-07-15}}</ref> one of the most important international [[marine ecology|marine]] environmental conventions. The convention was designed to minimize [[pollution]] of the seas from ships. The objective of the convention is to preserve the marine environment through the complete elimination of pollution by oil and other harmful substances and the minimization of accidental discharge of such substances.<ref>{{Cite web|title = IMO {{!}} History of IMO|url = http://www.imo.org/About/HistoryOfIMO/Pages/Default.aspx|website = www.imo.org|accessdate = 2015-06-03}}</ref> The Marpol Annex I began to be enforced on October 2, 1983, and it details the prevention of pollution by oil and oily water.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Marpol Annex 1 -Regulations for preventing oil pollution from ships|url = http://shipsbusiness.com/causes-of-pollution.html|website = shipsbusiness.com|accessdate = 2015-07-20}}</ref>
'''Marpol Annex I''' details the [[Effluent|discharge]] requirements for the prevention of pollution by oil and oily materials. It continues to enforce the oil discharge criteria described in the 1969 amendments to the 1954 Oil Pollution Convention.<ref>{{Cite web|title = 1978 Annex I of the 1978 Protocol relating to the 1973 International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships: Regulations for the Prevention of Pollution by Oil (Revised Version as of 2010) {{!}} Centre for International Law|url = http://cil.nus.edu.sg/1978/1978-annex-i-of-the-1978-protocol-relating-to-the-1973-international-convention-for-the-prevention-of-pollution-from-ships-regulations-for-the-prevention-of-pollution-by-oil-revised-version-as-of-20/|website = cil.nus.edu.sg|accessdate = 2015-07-22}}</ref> It also introduces the idea of "[http://www.imo.org/en/OurWork/Environment/SpecialAreasUnderMARPOL/Pages/Default.aspx special areas]" which are considered to be at risk to oil pollution. Discharge of oil within them have been completely outlawed but there are a few minor exceptions.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.imo.org/KnowledgeCentre/ReferencesAndArchives/HistoryofMARPOL/Documents/MARPOL%2073-78%20Brief%20History%20-%20List%20of%20amendments%20and%20how%20to%20find%20them.htm|title = MARPOL73-78: Brief history - list of amendments to date and where to find them|date = 2012|accessdate = June 2, 2015|website = MARPOL73-78: Brief history - list of amendments to date and where to find them|publisher = IMO|last = |first = }}</ref>
Also in 2003, in a joint effort [[International Maritime Organization|IMO]] and MEPC came out with [http://www.martinottaway.com/sites/martinottaway.com/files/users/Hannah%20van%20Hemmen/Document%2006.pdf Circ.406 Guidelines for Application of MARPOL Annex I Requirements to FPSOs and FSUs].<ref name=":0" />
Later in 2006, the United States Coast Guard [http://www.martinottaway.com/sites/martinottaway.com/files/users/Hannah%20van%20Hemmen/Document%2012%20-%20USCG%20Guidance%20for%20the%20Enforcement%20of%20MARPOL%20Annex%20I%20during%20Port%20State%20Control%20Exams%20.pdf published Guidance for the Enforcement of MARPOL Annex I During PSC Examinations].<ref name=":0" /> This was a [[United States Coast Guard|USCG]] policy letter that provided instruction to PSC officers with regard to [[Oil record book|Oil Record Book]], [[Oily Water Separator (marine)|Oily Water Separators]], and [[Oil content meter]] inspections during PSC visits.<ref name=":0" /> {| class="wikitable" !Chapter !Regulations !Topics |- |1 |1-5 |General: Definitions and Applications |- |2 |6-11 |Surveys and certification: Flag administration and Port State Control (PSC) |- |3 |12-17 |Machinery Space: Construction, discharge control and equipment (all ship types) |- |4 |18-36 |Cargo Areas: Construction, discharge control and equipment (oil tankers) |- |5 |37 |Shipboard oil pollution emergency plan (SOPEP) |- |6 |38 |Reception facilities |- |7 |39 |FPSOs and FSUs |} The first half of Marpol Annex I deals with [[engine room]] waste. There are many new technologies and equipment that have been developed to prevent waste such as: [[Oily Water Separator (marine)|Oily water separators]] (OWS), [[Oil Content Meter|Oil Content meters]] (OCM), and [[Port Reception Facilities]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARPOL)|url = http://www.imo.org/en/About/Conventions/ListOfConventions/Pages/International-Convention-for-the-Prevention-of-Pollution-from-Ships-(MARPOL).aspx|website = www.imo.org|accessdate = 2015-07-20}}</ref>
The second part of the Marpol Annex I has more to do with cleaning the cargo areas and tanks. [[Oil Discharge Monitoring Equipment]] (ODME) is a technology that has greatly helped improve efficiency and environmental protection in these areas.
== See also == * [[MARPOL 73/78|Marpol 73/78]] * [[International Maritime Organization|IMO]] * [[Oily Water Separators|Oily water separators]] * [[Oily Water Separator (marine)|Oily water separator (marine)]] * [[Oil Content Meter|Oil content meter]] * [[Oil Discharge Monitoring Equipment]] * [[Magic pipe|Magic Pipe]] * [[OCDMCS]]
== References == <references />
[[Category:Ocean pollution]]
